instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H? PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H is the input voltage to the PP3V42_G3H buck converter circuit, it can be either charger voltage or battery voltage depending on what the system power source is. This often shorts to ground when one of the input capacitors dies. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> Blows out
threads.message:
Hi
I have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board
As soon as I plugged charger to this Board, <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> Blow out. 
<RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>  not short to Ground. I tested with New <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> without <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> it gives me roughly 20v on both ends. As soon I Install <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> , <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> blows out. 
NO sign of Liquid damage on motherboard. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is also not short to ground, I checkd on F7140. I removed these components <CAPACITOR>C7090</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7091</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7092</CAPACITOR>, <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>   after <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> no sign of short. Could't figure out what is shorting. I replaced new chip also <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> still didn't solved my issue. I also replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> for no reason.
Now I need help where should I look.
Thanks in Advanced

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> Blows out
threads.message:
"I removed these components <CAPACITOR>C7090</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7091</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7092</CAPACITOR>, <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>   after <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> no sign of short. "
Did you check <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL> voltage after all removed?

Do not expect just pure short; why didn't post diode mode on all above tested points?
We need diode mode on L7095 too.

Check all components around <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>; pay atention to <CAPACITOR>C7094</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR>/96.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> Blows out
threads.message:
Thanks for Help
On diode mode at L7095 no short to ground (it does not beep when I try to connect probe to ground)
Removed <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> from Board, still new resistor blow out without it.
<RESISTOR>R7096</RESISTOR> is about 181K
<RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR> is about 360k
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL>  is 0.65v with broken resistor and components removed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> Blows out
threads.message:
"no short to ground (it does not beep "
Beep means short for you?
Multimeters beep until 060-075; is that still short for you?
On the other side, normal value on 3V42 rail is 300 aprox (diode mode I mean).
100 will not beep, but will be very bad.
These are the reasons I asked you for the real values...

"Removed <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> from Board, still new resistor blow out without it. "
Then your problem is not on 3V42 rails.
If is not one of <CAPACITOR>C7090</CAPACITOR>-92, then you have a problem between copper layers, inside board.
Did you even check diode mode on that point?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> Blows out
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C7090</CAPACITOR> was culprit, it was 100 ohm on diode mode and I didn't know it's bad. Sorry I didn't mention value on that Cap earlier.
Issue is solved and Board works like charm.

Thanks again for all your Help
[USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER] 5*
